item.title: Currently Reading
item.description: Currently Reading Marble Hall Murders by Anthony Horowitz An Inside Job by Daniel Silva

item.title: Books: Break In
item.description: Books: Break In I recently decided to revisit the mysteries of Dick Francis, many of which I had read in the 1990s, and found Break In at my local library. I remembered none of the details from my first reading so the story was essentially new to me. This is the first of two novels featuring English horse-racing jockey Kit Fielding, with the second book being Bolt. One thing I do recall liking about Francis’ stories is the insights they provided into various professions…

item.title: Books: The Illegals
item.description: Books: The Illegals I recently finished reading The Illegals: Russia’s Most Audacious Spies and Their Century-Long Mission to Infiltrate the West by Shaun Walker. Walker covers the history — from the Bolshevik revolution into the 21st century — of Russia’s program of training and deploying spies that immigrate to a country under a false identity, often residing there for years or even decades. They may gather intelligence regarding industrial or military capabilities.

item.title: Books: Return to Sender
item.description: Books: Return to Sender I recently finished reading Return to Sender, the latest entry in Craig Johnson’s long-running Walt Longmire mystery series, which was the basis for the popular Netflix series from a few years ago. After a couple flashback stories—First Frost and Tooth and Claw—the narrative returns to present day Wyoming, picking up where 2023’s The Longmire Defense left off. Sheriff Walt Longmire has been asked by a friend to investigate the disappearance of a mail carrier who failed to return from her 300-mile daily delivery route through southern Wyoming’s Red Desert…

item.title: Books: Andrea Camilleri's Inspector Montalbano
item.description: Books: Andrea Camilleri’s Inspector Montalbano Today I stumbled across Flaminia’s article from 2023 that looks at Sicilian author Andrea Camilleri and his popular Inspector Montalbano novels. I discovered these a couple years ago via my local library and am really enjoying them. On the Writer Who Created His Own Language

item.title: Books: The Amateur
item.description: Books: The Amateur The Amateur is a 1980 novel by Robert Littel, author of The Company and other espionage novels. It is the basis for the 2025 film of the same name. I haven’t watched the movie but I’m sure the book was better, since it almost always is, right? Berlin, 1972. Charlie Heller’s fiancee, Sarah, is taken hostage and murdered by terrorists. Heller works for the CIA–not as a field agent but rather as an analyst who decrypts confidential intercepted messages…

item.title: Books: The Devils Cave
Crime Fiction - Recent Reads
Books: 'On the Grid: Life Behind the Scenes of Formula 1'
Books: 'Leave the Gun, Take the Cannoli'
Cody Bellinger starts his swing.
Books: 'System Collapse'
The Voice in My Head
item.description: The Voice in My Head I’m reading a 1963 essay by James Bond author Ian Fleming, “How to Write a Thriller”, and I just realized that I hear it in my head as being read by George Sanders, ala his narration in “All About Eve”.

item.title: Books: 'The Woman in the Water'
item.description: Books: “The Woman in the Water” I recently finished reading The Woman in the Water by Charles Finch. This is a prequel to the popular Charles Lenox mystery series, set in Victorian London. I had read the first in the series, A Beautiful Blue Death, a few years ago and enjoyed it. The Woman in the Water is set many years earlier than other books in the series, in 1850. 23-year-old Charles Lenox has recently moved to London with his valet, Graham, with hopes of becoming a private detective.

item.title: Books: 'The Ghosts of Rome'
item.description: Books: “The Ghosts of Rome” I recently finished reading The Ghosts of Rome by Joseph O’Connor. This is the sequel to 2023’s My Father’s House, continuing the story of the Rome Escape Line, which helped escaped POWs remain in hiding or safely flee Italy altogether. Most of the major characters from the first book return in this one, but while the first book revolved around Monsignor Hugh O’Flaherty, this book revolves more around another of O’Flaherty’s Escape Line cohorts (aka ‘The Choir’), Contessa Giovanna ‘Jo’ Landini…

item.title: Books: 'The Last Manager'
item.description: Books: “The Last Manager: How Earl Weaver Tricked, Tormented, and Reinvented Baseball” I recently finished reading The Last Manager: How Earl Weaver Tricked, Tormented, and Reinvented Baseball* by John W. Miller. Long time Baltimore Orioles’ manager Earl Weaver is best remembered as a feisty, larger-than-life (but smaller than most men) character, going literally toe-to-toe with MLB umpires in legendary rants that fans loved and journalists loved to write about. But this chain-smoking, hard-drinking, foul-mouthed cartoon character was also a Baseball genius ahead of his time.

item.title: Books: 'Precipice'
Another Opening Day. Another Epic Fail for the MLB Mobile App.
item.description: Another Opening Day. Another Epic Fail for the MLB Mobile App. You might think that, after more than a decade, Major League Baseball’s “At Bat” mobile app would be pretty reliable. You would be wrong. Instead of live play-by-play audio, eager fans paying $20 a year were greeted with error messages and MLB’s equivalent of hold music. Read on Medium… Read on Substack….

item.title: Books: 'The Drowned'
How One Gamer Fell in Love with Reading
item.description: How One Gamer Fell in Love with Reading Kevin was “addicted to playing games for about 4 years”. He writes about his failed attempts to replace gaming with reading, and what ultimately worked for him. Eventually, he found himself falling in love with reading and wanting to read even more. And he provides tips on how you might “replace a habit like gaming with something more productive”. Read Kevin’s story here.

item.title: Books: 'The Unpleasantness at the Bellona Club'
item.description: Books: “The Unpleasantness at the Bellona Club” I recently finished reading The Unpleasantness at the Bellona Club by Dorothy L. Sayers. Published in 1928, this is the fifth book featuring Sayers’ famous amateur detective Lord Peter Wimsey. Martin Edwards makes many mentions of Ayers in his history of mystery writing, The Life of Crime, which I recently enjoyed. So I thought I should at least give it a go. Read more…

item.title: Books: 'The Life of Crime' by Martin Edwards
item.description: Books: ‘The Life of Crime’ by Martin Edwards I just finished reading The Life of Crime: Detecting the History of Mysteries and their Creators by Martin Edwards. This 2022 release is a 622-page comprehensive history of mystery writing, from the eighteenth century to the present. Each chapter contains numerous footnotes, and the book includes a bibliography and two indexes at the back: an Index of Titles and an Index of Names.

item.title: Books: 'Karla's Choice'
item.description: Books: ‘Karla’s Choice’ by Nick Harkaway I just finished reading Karla’s Choice by Nick Harkaway. The cover identifies this as “A John Le Carré Novel”, though Le Carré — who passed away in 2020 — did not write it. Harkaway, an established novelist in his own right, is also the son of the late spy novelist John Le Carré. Karla’s Choice is set in the world of British agent George Smiley — the world that Le Carré created — and slots in between The Spy Who Came in from the Cold (1963) and The Looking Glass War (1965).

item.title: Books: 'Broken Trust: A Spenser Novel'
item.description: Books: ‘Broken Trust: A Spenser Novel’ by Mike Lupica I recently finished reading Broken Trust by Mike Lupica, the 50th title in the Spenser series. A little background… Robert B. Parker created Boston private detective Spenser (“no first name”) in 1973 with The Godwulf Manuscript and continued through Sixkill, published posthumously in 2011. Sixkill was the 39th Spenser novel. Along the way (1985–1988), there was a Spenser: For Hire TV series starring Robert Urich.

item.title: In the Beginning, There Was Motown...
item.description: In the Beginning, There Was Motown… We recently attended a Motown tribute concert, and I was struck by the fact that many songs that I had long associated with post-Motown artists were originally Motown hits many years before. Here are just a few examples… Read more…

item.title: The Incomparable Ricky Jay
item.description: The Incomparable Ricky Jay I think I first encountered Ricky Jay in David Mamet’s House of Games with Joe Mantegna and Lindsay Crouse. He would pop up now and again over the years in films and TV episodes, including the final season of Sneaky Pete, his last on-screen work. I enjoyed his crafty, cynical, world-weary con men wherever they made an appearance… Read more…

item.title: Books: 'The Wrong Hands' by Mark Billingham
item.description: Books: ‘The Wrong Hands’ by Mark Billingham I was browsing the New Releases shelves at one of my local libraries (we have library cards for three local systems) when I stumbled upon The Wrong Hands by Mark Billingham. I wasn’t familiar with this British author but he has a long-running series of books featuring an inspector Tom Thorne. The Wrong Hands is the second book in a different series featuring detective Declan Miller.

item.title: Books: 'Blood Curse' by Maurizio de Giovanni
Books: 'The Siege' by Ben Macintyre
Artificial Intelligence. For Dummies.
item.description: Artificial Intelligence. For Dummies. I see that my local public library has added the following book: Artificial Intelligence for Dummies I don’t plan to read it; I just found the title interesting.

item.title: Books: 'The Why is Everything' by Michael Silver
item.description: Books: ‘The Why Is Everything: A Story of Football, Rivalry, and Revolution’ by Michael Silver I just finished reading The Why Is Everything: A Story of Football, Rivalry, and Revolution by Michael Silver. Silver is a sportswriter currently writing for The Athletic and has previously written for Sports Illustrated and the San Francisco Chronicle, among others. In The Why Is Everything, Silver documents the rise of a young generation of NFL coaches, many of whom started or developed under long-time NFL head coach Mike Shanahan.

item.title: Books: 'Safe Houses' by Dan Fesperman
item.description: Books: ‘Safe Houses’ by Dan Fesperman In another post, I mentioned that most main characters in espionage stories are either professional spies or unwitting amateurs. That article highlighted the failed professionals of Mick Herron’s Slow Horses / Slough House series, who fall somewhat in between. In Dan Fesperman’s Safe Houses, Helen Abell falls into this gap, as well, but from a different angle. Helen works on the fringe of the espionage business, managing safe houses for the CIA in 1979 Berlin.

item.title: The Slow Horses of Slough House
Books: 'How We Got to Now: Six Innovations That Made the Modern World' by Steven Johnson

item.description: Book Discovery Resources Here, fellow booklovers, are a few online resources to help you discover your next great read, whether through targeted selection or serendipity. Enjoy! Read more…

item.title: Books: 'Bad Debts' by Peter Temple
item.description: Books: ‘Bad Debts’ by Peter Temple I first stumbled across Jack Irish on Acorn TV. It was (or should I say ‘is’, in today’s perpetual-life-via-streaming world?) an Australian TV series (and movies) starring Guy Pearce (LA Confidential, Memento, The King’s Speech). I enjoyed the TV series very much and recently sought out Peter Temple’s novels, on which the TV series is based. Read more…
